prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for lying to my wife?
Hopefully this is not as cut and dry as it may seem. A couple years ago a female coworker (we’ll call her Liz) started dating another girl. Up until this point, Liz was straight. Apparently Liz eventually found out that her girlfriend had been lying to her and had been doing some pretty shady (and illegal) stuff. Liz was obviously upset by this and was confiding in me via text. I was reading the text to my wife to fill her in on the situation and in a long stream of texts, Liz said something like “I haven’t had sex with a guy in two years. I don’t know if I want to continue in this relationship.” I responded with “I know I vent to you about my wife a lot, but I love her more than anything and can’t imagine my life without her. If you don’t feel like you can’t live without her, then you need to end it.” My wife took that as “she wants to have sex with you and all you do is talk shit about me to her.” As much as I tried to convince her otherwise, she wasn’t having it. She basically told me she didn’t want me to be friends with Liz anymore. To appease her, I told her I wouldn’t. However, Liz and I stayed friends at work. Fast forward to this week, and my wife has been acting unreasonably angry towards me. (Not to be a dick, but it is that time of the month, and she does get very moody). So I just gave her some space. Today, she confronts me that she went through my phone and saw that I had been texting with Liz and that I lied to her about not being friends with her anymore. AITA for not telling her I’m still friends with Liz, or is my wife that asshole for telling me I can’t be and then going through my phone?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author lied to his wife about still being friends with a female coworker named Liz. The wife found out through her phone, which she went through, and now there's a conflict.

First, I need to break down the key points. The author initially had a conversation with Liz where things got a bit personal. The author then relayed this to his wife, but his wife misunderstood, thinking the author was suggesting Liz wanted to have sex with him. The wife then told him not to be friends with Liz anymore. The author agreed not to, but continued being friends at work. Later, the wife found out he was still texting Liz, hence the lie.

So, the main issue is about honesty in the marriage. The author didn't follow through on the promise to cut ties with Liz, which he told his wife he would do. Even though he might have had a reason to stay friendly at work, keeping that secret and not being truthful about it could be seen as a breach of trust. 

But wait, the author might say he was just trying to keep the peace, since his wife was already upset. However, lying about it led to a bigger problem. Also, the wife's method of checking his phone is not ideal, but that doesn't justify the husband's lie. The question is whether the husband is in the wrong for lying. 

In relationships, honesty is crucial. Even if the wife's actions (checking the phone) were wrong, lying to her about a promise he made can't be right. The author didn't have a valid reason to continue texting Liz if he had promised not to. So, the lie is the main issue here. Therefore, the answer is A.
